title: Data Protection Commissioner v Facebook Ireland Limited and Maximillian Schrems (Schrems II)
court: Court of Justice of the European Union
summary: Landmark ruling invalidating the EU-US Privacy Shield framework for transatlantic data transfers. The Court found that US surveillance laws do not provide adequate protection for EU citizens' data, requiring additional safeguards for transfers based on Standard Contractual Clauses.

title: Google Spain SL v Agencia Española de Protección de Datos (Right to be Forgotten)
court: Court of Justice of the European Union
summary: Landmark ruling establishing the 'right to be forgotten' under EU data protection law. The Court held that search engine operators are data controllers and must consider requests to remove links to personal information from search results.

title: Fashion ID GmbH & Co. KG v Verbraucherzentrale NRW eV
court: Court of Justice of the European Union
summary: German reference case establishing that website operators embedding third-party plugins (like Facebook 'Like' buttons) can be joint controllers for data collection. Clarified responsibilities and consent requirements for embedded social media features.

title: Bundesverband der Verbraucherzentralen v Planet49 GmbH
court: Court of Justice of the European Union
summary: German reference case establishing that pre-ticked checkboxes do not constitute valid consent for cookies. Confirmed that active, informed consent is required for storing cookies, and users must be informed about cookie duration and third-party access.

title: Unabhängiges Landeszentrum für Datenschutz Schleswig-Holstein v Wirtschaftsakademie Schleswig-Holstein GmbH
court: Court of Justice of the European Union
summary: German reference case ruling that Facebook fan page administrators are joint controllers with Facebook for processing visitor data. Established that entities using social media platforms share responsibility for data protection compliance.

title: Maximillian Schrems v Data Protection Commissioner (Schrems I)
court: Court of Justice of the European Union
summary: Landmark ruling invalidating the EU-US Safe Harbor framework. The Court found that the Commission's adequacy decision was invalid because US surveillance practices did not ensure adequate protection for EU citizens' fundamental rights.

title: Digital Rights Ireland Ltd v Minister for Communications
court: Court of Justice of the European Union
summary: Landmark ruling invalidating the Data Retention Directive as incompatible with fundamental rights. The Court found that blanket data retention constitutes a serious interference with privacy and data protection rights without adequate safeguards.

title: GC and Others v Commission nationale de l'informatique et des libertés (CNIL)
court: Court of Justice of the European Union
summary: Clarified the scope of the right to delisting for search engines. The Court ruled that search engines must generally delist links to sensitive personal data but established a balancing test considering public interest and freedom of information.

title: Google LLC v Commission nationale de l'informatique et des libertés (CNIL)
court: Court of Justice of the European Union
summary: Addressed the territorial scope of the right to be forgotten. The Court ruled that EU law does not require global delisting but allows national authorities to order worldwide removal on a case-by-case basis where justified.

title: Orange România SA v Autoritatea Națională de Supraveghere a Prelucrării Datelor cu Caracter Personal (ANSPDCP)
court: Court of Justice of the European Union
summary: Clarified GDPR consent requirements in the context of mobile phone contracts. Confirmed that consent must be freely given, specific, and demonstrated by clear affirmative action, and that pre-ticked boxes or bundled consent is invalid.

title: Privacy International v Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs
court: Court of Justice of the European Union
summary: Ruled that national legislation requiring bulk transmission of traffic and location data to security services for national security purposes is incompatible with EU law. Established limits on mass surveillance powers.

title: La Quadrature du Net and Others v Premier ministre
court: Court of Justice of the European Union
summary: Major ruling on mass surveillance and data retention. The Court found that general and indiscriminate retention of traffic and location data is prohibited, while targeted retention for serious crime and national security may be permitted with safeguards.

title: Facebook Ireland Ltd v Gegevensbeschermingsautoriteit
court: Court of Justice of the European Union
summary: Clarified the one-stop-shop mechanism and lead supervisory authority under GDPR. Established when non-lead supervisory authorities can exercise powers in cross-border processing cases and the conditions for urgent procedures.

title: Meta Platforms Ireland Limited v Bundesverband der Verbraucherzentralen
court: Court of Justice of the European Union
summary: Addressed consumer associations' standing to bring GDPR claims and the legal bases for processing personal data for personalized advertising. Confirmed that consumer protection associations can bring actions for GDPR violations.

title: Meta Platforms Inc. v Bundeskartellamt
court: Court of Justice of the European Union
summary: Landmark ruling on the intersection of competition law and data protection. Confirmed that competition authorities can consider GDPR compliance when assessing abuse of dominant position, particularly regarding consent and data combination practices.

title: Ligue des droits humains v Conseil des ministres
court: Court of Justice of the European Union
summary: Addressed the validity of the PNR Directive (passenger name records) and its compatibility with fundamental rights. The Court upheld the directive but required strict interpretation and limiting the scope of data processing.

title: Republic of Poland v European Parliament and Council of the European Union
court: Court of Justice of the European Union
summary: Upheld the Copyright Directive's upload filter provisions (Article 17). The Court found that while the measures restrict freedom of expression, they include sufficient safeguards to ensure proportionality and protect user rights.

title: Nacionalinis visuomenės sveikatos centras v Valstybinė duomenų apsaugos inspekcija
court: Court of Justice of the European Union
summary: Clarified conditions for GDPR compensation claims. Established that mere infringement of GDPR is not sufficient for damages; claimants must prove actual harm suffered, though the threshold for non-material damages should not be set too high.

title: UI v Österreichische Post AG
court: Court of Justice of the European Union
summary: Key ruling on GDPR non-material damages. Confirmed that compensation under Article 82 GDPR requires proof of damage, but there is no de minimis threshold. Non-material damage such as distress or discomfort can be compensated.

title: BL v Saturn Electro-Handelsgesellschaft mbH (MediaMarktSaturn)
court: Court of Justice of the European Union
summary: Clarified the scope of the GDPR right of access under Article 15. Addressed what information must be provided when a data subject requests access, including the identity of recipients and the scope of 'copy' of personal data.
